video.title: The Games of 2023 I Didn't Review | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

There are many reasons why a game might escape my 
review treatment - maybe there just wasn&#39;t a spot

to squeeze it in, maybe the theme wasn&#39;t my cup 
of tea or the genre wasn&#39;t my hypodermic of jizz,

maybe I just plain no second hand spunk mops 
couldn&#39;t be arsed. So here are my thoughts on

some of the overlooked games I played in 2023. 
With the year behind us I can now at least be

arsed to do a roundup of quickie reviews, 
because there&#39;s nothing quite like an arse

roundup when you&#39;re in the mood for a quickie. 
Huh. That made sense when I got up this morning.
PIZZA TOWER

A darling of the indies from early in the year 
that more people asked me to review than asked

me to stop posting videos and commit suicide, 
which is always a good sign. Commenters tend

to assume that if I don&#39;t review a game 
it&#39;s only ever because I secretly love it

and can&#39;t think of enough mean sweary 
ways to describe it. Well guess what,

Youtube plankton: you&#39;re the closest to being 
right you&#39;ve ever been. I do like Pizza Tower.

I like the anarchic energy of the visuals and 
how it looks like a Cartoon Network show from

that period in the late 90s when every 
character had to look like a partially

emptied ballsack on the floor of a laundry 
room for some reason. I like the innovative

core platforming mechanics and it&#39;s clearly 
one of those games I prize that give an awful

lot of shit about looking like it doesn&#39;t give a 
shit. Here&#39;s why I didn&#39;t stick with it, though:

I can&#39;t play it for more than two or three levels 
before I get completely stressed out. Having to

run backwards through each level with a time 
limit at the end is a nice idea that I appreciate,

but I&#39;ve been ruined by endless metroidvanias 
making me want to check every crevice and labia

in the environment so having to do that under 
pressure is more anxiety-inducing than fun.

Maybe the game shouldn&#39;t have had a hub between 
levels. I said in my Armored Core 6 review,

when a game has to ask me if I want to 
continue between every fucking mission,

it runs the risk of my answer being &quot;No, 
thinking about it. At least give me ten

minutes to get back in the mood by looking 
through these old Domino&#39;s takeout menus.&quot;
COCOON

I was dismissive of Cocoon at first glance 
because it seemed like one of the many

flavours of generic arty indie game I 
deal with - isometric explore-a-thon,

unknown protagonist in lonely alien landscape, 
interpretive plot, understated soundtrack,

general vibe of a Lawrence of Arabia establishing 
shot, but the turning point came when I pressed

a button and suddenly jumped out of the world, 
which it turns out was contained in a fishbowl

in a weird alien interactive science museum. And 
before long we find more worlds in more fishbowls

that you can put inside other worlds and even 
in themselves to solve these nutty mobius strips

of puzzles and it&#39;s all jolly absorbing from a 
game design perspective. But now I feel like I&#39;m

waiting for the game that does something fun with 
it story-wise. It&#39;d be perfect for my pitch for a

game adaptation of Being John Malkovich that got 
me thrown out of the Universal executive toilets.
SANABI

Pixel arty 2D platformy affair best summarised as 
&quot;Katana Zero meets Celeste meets a grappling hook,

followed by a whirlwind romance and joyful 
marriage to a grappling hook.&quot; With a plot

straight out of the &quot;grim middle-aged murder man 
haunted by lost loved one finds second chance at

redemption while escorting innocent child&quot; hairy 
dad playbook, but I can&#39;t hold that against it,

because hey, grappling hook. One of those 
would&#39;ve certainly improved The Last Of Us,

if it&#39;d been used to tether the main characters 
to a speeding bus. Core gameplay&#39;s fun,

easy to learn and hard to master and evolves 
in all the right ways as you go through, but

it doesn&#39;t build to an impactful climax for me. 
Partly because of the lack of a meaty final boss,

partly the plot dragging the conclusion out 
a bit too long. It&#39;s got some nice twists,

but I slightly resent a story where the twist 
hinges on your character&#39;s memory being false.

Not in the James Sunderland unreliable narrator 
way, in the &quot;Hey all these establishing scenes

we showed you were outright lies&quot; way. 
I mean, what chance does that give me?

Maybe the whole plot&#39;s lies. Maybe it&#39;s all 
happening inside the mind of a dying seagull.
JUSANT

I&#39;m actually a keen indoor rock climber IRL - 
well I was, it&#39;s hard to find time away from

the kids while I&#39;m unwilling to duct tape them 
to my spine - and it&#39;s rare to find a climbing

mechanic that really evokes the feeling of it 
- the taking of strain, the shifting of weight,

the having to shake chalk dust off of everything 
you&#39;re stupid enough to put in the same backpack

as your harness - but Jusant has a pretty good 
go at it, as our protagonist muddles their way

through climbing up an abandoned post-apocalyptic 
post-ocean society that was set up on a vertical

wall for some reason, possibly &#39;cos no one could 
agree on who would get the window seat. It&#39;s fun

enough, but at a certain point it seems to stop 
being about combing through the remnants of a

departed society and just goes &quot;Oh fuck it, I&#39;m 
bored, space whales out of nowhere.&quot; And I mean,

literal space whales, not what I call 
your mum when she&#39;s on the gummies.
IMMORTALS OF AVEUM

It&#39;s a shame I didn&#39;t finish Game With Title 
So Forgettable I Literally Forgot It As I Was

Saying This, because it had the kind of pure 
blandness energy that could have powered the

Bland 5 list from here to Callisto and back. 
It&#39;s a first person action adventure with not

particularly fun magic-based shooter combat 
that has that Ghostwire Tokyo problem wherein

making rude gestures at things just isn&#39;t 
as intuitive or enjoyable as blasting their

wrinkly giblets off with a big juicy shotgun, and 
its only noteworthy quality is that the plot is,

in a nutshell, Hackneyed Young Adult Fantasy 
Novel: The Game. You play a street urchin with

a weirdly expensive haircut in an oppressive 
fantasy city who runs afoul of the evil empire

but discovers they&#39;ve got special magic 
powers and falls under the tutelage of

a stern but good-hearted mentor and so on and 
so on. I thought it best to pack it in before

the game&#39;s protagonist needed to pick which of 
two troubled hunky boys he most wanted to snog.
HUMANITY

A Japanese puzzle game where you play a magic 
shiny dog dropping instructions in the path of

a stream of aimlessly wandering humanity, to 
save them, rather than as one might expect,

to get ironic revenge for Crufts. Which made me 
go, you&#39;re right, Humanity, why don&#39;t we ever

see games like Lemmings anymore? Not entirely like 
Lemmings, of course, Lemmings penalised you if you

let too many of your column of adorable squeaky 
charges march trustingly to their gory deaths,

whereas in Humanity you can watch streams of 
humanoids plunge off cliffs for as long as it

takes to process whatever it is that&#39;s going on in 
your vile head, which for me sucks the fun out of

simulated genocide. Still, it was nice to see. 
And speaking of the complete opposite of that:
CALL OF DUTY: MODERN WARFARE 3

Didn&#39;t play it, never will. See, I played the 
Modern Warfare 1 remake but when MW2 came around,

I thought to myself, &quot;You know what? This does 
not spark joy.&quot; And I wish I could bottle the

sensation of realising that I could just NOT 
play Modern Warfare games anymore. I&#39;d make a

fucking fortune. &quot;Doctor, I&#39;m feeling really 
depressed, anxious and inadequate as a man.&quot;

I prescribe four hundred milligrams of never 
playing Modern Warfare games again. &quot;Gosh, I

feel better already. And with a much more nuanced 
view on unsanctioned foreign interventionism.&quot;
